faq.title: Parsing HTML Generated an Error.
faq.q: I tried to use &javaparsername; to parse an HTML file and it generated an error. What did I do wrong?

a.p: Unfortunately, HTML does not, in general, follow the XML grammar rules. Most HTML files do not meet the XML style quidelines. Therefore, the XML parser generates XML well-formedness errors.

ul.li:
Missing end tags, e.g.

with no

(end tags are not required in HTML)
Missing closing slash on (not required in HTML)
Missing quotes on attribute values, e.g. (not generally required in HTML)

a.p: HTML must match the XHTML standard for well-formedness before it can be parsed by Xerces-J or any other XML parser. You can find the XHTML standard on the W3C web site.

faq.title: UTF-8 Character Error
faq.q: I get an "invalid UTF-8 character" error.

a.p: There are many Unicode characters that are not allowed in an XML document, according to the XML spec. Typical disallowed characters are control characters, even if you escape them using the Character Reference form: &#xxxx; . See the XML spec, sections 2.2 and 4.1 for details. If the parser is generating this error, it is very likely that there is a character in the file that you can not see. You can generally use a UNIX command like "od -hc" to find it.

faq.title: Error Accessing EBCDIC XML Files
faq.q: I get an error when I access EBCDIC XML files, what is happening?

a.p: If an XML document/file is not UTF-8, then you MUST specify the encoding. When transcoding a UTF8 document to EBCDIC, remember to change this:

ul.li:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
to something like this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ebcdic-cp-us"?>

faq.title: EOF Character Error
faq.q: I get an error on the EOF character (0x1A) -- what is happening?

a.p: You are probably using the LPEX editor, which automatically inserts an End-of-file character (0x1A) at the end of your XML document (other editors might do this as well). Unfortunately, the EOF character (0x1A) is an illegal character according to the XML specification, and &javaparsername; correctly generates an error.

faq.title: DOS Filenames No Longer Work
faq.q: I used to be able to use DOS filenames with the parser and now they don't work. Why not?

a.p: DOS filenames are not legal URIs as required by the XML 1.0 specification. Therefore, it was an error for the parser to accept DOS filenames. This bug is now fixed.
DOS filenames can be converted to legal URIs, however. For example, the DOS filename "c:\xerces\data\personal.xml" would become "file:///c:/xerces/data/personal.xml", which is a legal URI.
